text: let's listen in then to sue hemming
who's from the Crown Prosecution Service
at the turn of the year the CTS received
the first full file of evidence from
operation resolve and the Independent
Police Complaints Commission in relation
to their investigations into the
Hillsborough disaster and the events
which followed the operation resolved
files comprised approximately 85,000
pages and the IPCC South Yorkshire
Police file in excess of 30,000 pages
additionally there's estimated to be up
to a million pages of unused material
which needed to be assessed operation
resolved investigated the events of the
15th of April 1989 when 96 Liverpool
fans were tragically killed as the
result of overcrowding they referred
files in respect of 15 suspects the IPCC
investigated the aftermath in particular
they looked at the conduct of the South
Yorkshire Police whether anyone was
responsible for a cover-up of the true
event and if witness statements were
altered in such a way as to amount to a
criminal offence they referred files in
respect of six suspects on this aspect
of the case there is a further IPCC file
into the conduct of the West Midlands
Police which amounted to about 60,000
pages but additional investigative work
was required in respect of this
additionally just this week the IPCC has
referred to further suspects which are
unconnected to the matters sent to us in
January these subjects are subject to
ongoing consideration by the CPS and we
will announce our decisions in due
course the suspects referred to the CPF
included individuals and organisations
following these thorough investigations
and our careful review of the evidence
in accordance with the Code for crown
prosecutors I have decided that there is
sufficient evidence to charge six
individuals with criminal offences these
are summarized as follows there is
sufficient evidence to charge former
chief
David duckenfield with the manslaughter
by gross negligence of 95 men women and
children mr. duggenfield was the match
commander on the day of the disaster in
order to prosecute this matter the CPS
will need to apply to the High Court
judge to remove the stay imposed at the
end of his 1999 private prosecution this
process will commence shortly we are
unable to charge the mound sauter of
Anthony bland the 96 casualty who died
almost four years later this is due to
time limitations imposed by the law as
it applied at the time former Chief
Constable Norman betterthan is charged
with four offenses of misconduct in
public office this relates to alleged
lies he told about his involvement in
the aftermath of Hillsborough and the
culpability of fans Graham Henry
Mackrell is charged with two offenses of
contravening a term or condition of a
safety certificate contrary to the
safety of sports grounds Act 1975 he is
additionally charged with one offense of
failing to take reasonable care for the
health and safety of other persons who
may have been affected by his acts or
omissions at work under the Health and
Safety at Work Act 1974 mr. McRoy was
Sheffield Wednesday Football Club's
company secretary and Safety Officer at
the time Peter Metcalfe is charged with
doing acts with intent to pervert the
course of public justice relating to
material changes made to witness
statements mr. Metcalfe was the
solicitor acting for the South Yorkshire
police during the Taylor inquiry and the
first inquest former Chief
Superintendent Donnell Denton and former
Detective Chief Inspector Alan Foster
a charge of the same offense for their
involvement in changes made to witness
statements
the defendants other than David
duckenfield will all appear at
Warrington Magistrates Court on the 9th
of August criminal proceedings have now
commenced and the defendants have a
right to a fair trial it is extremely
important that there should be no
reporting commentary or show
of information online which could in any
way prejudice these proceedings
I have not authorized charges in
relation to any other individuals or
organizations the reason for these
decisions are set out in a written
summary that we've published today
